author: fenquick

title: Plate Leveling Tabs For Rep 2 Platform

description.text:
The plate leveling card MakerBot provides doesn't last forever. I also feel like I don't always get my leveling right all the time.
Use these tabs to check adhesion on your platform at all corners and the center areas too. The tabs are 0.4mm thick to test at 0.2mm and 0.1mm layer heights. The print is fast and uses very little plastic. Great for really dialing in your platform just before an important print. This file is specifically for the Rep2 platform. Inspired by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60522 I thought it would be useful to have tabs at all corners and the center. Sometime I print things at the edges and they fall off regardless of my calibration with the card.
If a tab is smeared then tighten the screw at that area. If a tab comes off, then loosen the screw 1/16th to 1/8th a turn until it sticks reliably.

author: fenquick

description.text: Una piccola scatola porta oggetti, per fare ordine dove volete voi!

This thing is a trombone mouthpiece with boatloads of parameters. It can be customized in customizer. You should be able to reasonably approximate more or less any rotationally symmetric mouthpiece out there.  
I mostly use my printed mouthpieces for warming up in the car on my way to rehearsal. On the bass trombone, I find that printed mouthpieces are extremely warm sounding, almost Euphonium-like.  
The default parameters will give you something vaguely resembling a 4G size mouthpiece.  
Updated: 2013-03-30 with a new set of parameters for improved cup geometry based on an analysis of several commercial mouthpiece curves.  
Updated: 2013-04-13 with improvements to the outside geometry and a couple simplifications to try (unsuccessfully) to make it work with customizer. OpenSCAD reports that the file compiles to a valid, simple 3D object, but customizer is unable to generate an STL file.  
However, you can always download the scad file and edit it with OpenSCAD.

Brass-instrument mouthpieces are subtly complicated objects, with many distinguishing features that are at or beyond the resolution of current consumer printers. But it's still pretty cool to be able to print your own, even if it's not going to replace your fancy Greg Black.
And they're hard to print. If you could print them rim-side down, it'd be a lot easier. But then you have to print with a flat rim and manually apply all of the subtle shaping that makes a rim comfortable and well-playing. Plus, the interior slope on many cups would exceed 45deg at some point. So, it's best to print the mouthpiece with the rim-side up, but that presents other challenges.
The current design defaults to printing the cup/rim and shank in two pieces, in an attempt to make it easier to get a successful print. I use bezier curves to define the shape of the cup and of the rim. I chose the control points by eyeball. The outer shape of the cup is mostly determined to be printable without support, at least if you use a non-pathological set of parameters.
The trick is getting a nice smooth finish, especially on the portions of the rim that contact your face. For best results, I print in ABS at 0.1mm layer height, then sand lightly before putting the mouthpiece in a rice-cooker acetone vapor bath. I'm still working out the optimal vapor-bath procedure. The shank is fairly fragile, and it's easy to overdo the acetone and melt your mouthpiece.
If you print the cup only (see the Printer tab in Customizer) with a large-shank, it should be adaptable for use with a Doug Elliott shank. When the mouthpiece is still slightly soft after it has been out of the vapor bath for an hour or so, you can carefully thread the Elliott shank into the printed cup. That's not a bad way to go if you've got an Elliott shank.

title: Allit Europlus Flex Insert
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Lets you create modular inserts for the Allit Europlus Flex module cases.
It is also possible to add dividers that run parallel to the column. Since I used OpenSCADs hull function to create this part, the preview of the model will take longer to render, and in some instances render the cases as if they are closed. Please notice that this ONLY happens in the rendering and NOT in the final print.

All that is needed to do is:
Enter the number of Rows, Columns and Dividers. No support material is required. IMPORTANT:
Remember that the dividers run parallel to the column.

A dispenser for small dog/cat dry food to keep your pet amused. Designed it originally for my daughter's puppy, but works well with our cocker spaniel as well.
You put the treats in the open end where they sit in the centre cavity. When your pet rolls it along the floor, the treats are guided through a helix at either end and pop out on the floor for them to eat.
Would only recommend using it under supervision as initially our spaniel thought that it may be easier to take it out onto the lawn and attempt to bite it to break it open. They are made out of PLA, so I don't think that would be too pleasant on the dog's mouth if they crunched it. So watch out using it with dogs that have a big enough bite to break the plastic. I made a couple out of clear PLA, but that probably isn't necessary for the pets as they smell the food inside. The toy is 75mm (3") diameter and 125mm (4.9") long

I printed it with clear PLA using a fill of 0.6, but it probably doesn't matter too much as most surfaces are too thin to use the fill function. Because it is printed on its side, I sliced it without supports (no way of removing them inside) and instead added some initial rafting and support for the lower part of the curve. It printed surprising well and took my Printrbot 7.5 hours to do the print.
After printing I cut the supports and raft off and then sanded it smooth enough to make it roundish.

comments.text:
Nice. I have now printed 3 of these. However, there seem to be a
design flaw: In the center spiral, the spiral is too thin, almost razor
thin, and my machine cannot print this thin. This leaves defects in the
spiral. Drop me a line and I can explain. Maybe you can improve the
design?
comments.author: ralfselfjord

comments.text: At a quarter size, it’s a sprinkle dispenser for my rats. As soon as they stop just trying to eat it. Which may not happen.
comments.author: Equisetophyta

comments.text: Great to hear it has another application. My daughter's dog is still happy to roll it around to get the food from it. I made a smaller prototype version, our spaniel decided the best way to get food from it was to take it outside and try to chew it open. No longer an issue with the larger version.

description.text:
THIS FILE IS PROPORTIONED IN INCHES. SET REPETIER OR YOUR CONTROLLER PROGRAM TO IMPORT FILES IN INCHES.  
After witnessing my father knock a bottle of insulin off the table yesterday, I designed this holder to simply hold 2 10ml bottles of Humulin or Novolin and a standard syringe. The center socket has a hole designed for a #8 pan head wood screw or #6-32 machine screw. It could also be mounted with adhesive-backed velcro, mounting tape, sticky putty or whatever you like.

THIS FILE IS PROPORTIONED IN INCHES. SET REPETIER OR YOUR CONTROLLER PROGRAM TO IMPORT FILES IN INCHES.
I printed in natural ABS and simply colored the flat surface of the letters with a Sharpie. Using a 1/64" nozzle (aka .4mm for you pitiable, misguided metric-lovers) this is a very economical thing to print, as the walls are only 2 layers thick. This fits the 1/3 oz (aka 10mL) Humulin and Novolin bottles. There's a taller- and thinner-bottled kind of insulin out there that won't fit securely but will obviously still fit.

author: draj1968

description.text:
This is a version of merlinjim's Rose for Unicorn Pen Plotter that uses a hatching pattern to fill in the weighted lines. This drawing works well with a fine-nibbed art pen like a Pigma Micron 3 or 1. Bonus points to someone willing to go back to the original and work out a multi-pass version using delicate touches with a brush pen to re-create the this work to match the original illustration (with a variation in line weights), or create a tool for ranges of line weights! You will definitely be wanting schmarty's Inkscape Unicorn extensions for this piece. And my calibration test image might help you troubleshoot the settings in schmarty's tool (and tensions for your belts in your bot).
And you should also grab the Eggbot Inkscape extensions to get a copy of dnewman's Inkscape hatch fill extension to use for solving fill issues like this one quickly and elegantly

The gcode here runs pretty well on my bot -- center it on the build platform and use a sticky-note or larger paper. But where the hatches fall outside of the outlines you will want to return to the SVG file and adjust the timings for elements of the print so that the pen is properly down to the paper before drawing, and lifting at the right moment before moving into position for the next line, etc..

comments.text: You rock.
comments.author: merlinjim

comments.text:
No, you rock. Seriously. If you fuss with how to prep the Inkscape files for these prints, the Eggbotters will also go crazy for these. Oh, here's an Inkscape trick: select View
&
gt; Display
&
gt; Outline so that you can preview the paths that the script will be running.
comments.author: merlinjim

title: UltiRouter v0.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is the wooden parts for a a router, with a stackable design that stacks onto the Ultimaker. This is just an early draft, as some dimensions need to be changed, like the diameter of the X-axis shafts.

If you feel the need to make/adapt this design, here are some brief routing descriptions. The drawing is laid out for cutting with a 3 and 5 mm flat tip end mill. Some layers in the dxf have a numeric prefix, follow this sequence for the routing order. I usually fix the parts to the routing table with a few screws in the first holes layer. Reference the drawing to make sure you fix each part at a safe place. This thing is based on the plans of both the Ultimaker 3d printer http://ultimaker.com (thing:8563) and the mantis-30 router (thing:6115), which in itself is a derivative of the mantis design by David Carr http://makeyourbot.org/mantis9-1 This is a work in progress, I intend to increase the size of the axis shafts, add some construction for a hinged front/top and various other things before I make a complete prototype.

author: alumin

title: Ghost FPV Rail mounting System with Landing Skids V2

description.text: This is a FPV landing system i created to use 8mm carbon fiber tubes as a rail system. You can mount batteries or camera gimbals to it and an assortment of other things. More to come!

***NEW Added dual-battery carrier
New Half Landing Skids (for easier printing replacement)
Pixhawk Lite (or similar size) FC vibe mount. It slides over the screws of the frame
GPS Mount for 8mm CF tube. mounts in one of the square 10x10 holes on the board.

What's needed
2x rail mounts
2x legs
4x 8mm carbon fiber tubes (12" long)
2x battery clips with rubber band.
2x FPV clips for Tarot T2D gimbal The 4S battery clip works with a 4S 5000mAh Turnigy battery, the 6S is a 5500mAh non-name. If you want one for a specific battery size, mention it in the comments and i'll make one. Make sure you use a pretty strong rubber band, the stronger it is, the better it'll "grip" the battery and prevent it from sliding out. I printed with ABS @238C, 4-5 shells with 20-25% fill. Keeps it pretty light and strong.

comments.text:

title: Single Print - Hot Wheels Car (Matchbox )
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is meant to be a no assembly, no supports toy car that can be done in a single print. The size is based off of Matchbox and Hot Wheels cars and I am including the SketchUp file to encourage folks to do a Christmas hackathon along with me. The axle is trapped and the wheels are tapered so it shouldn't need supports. Also we just added a space for some pennies to add weight for that orange hot wheels track! New Version:
Version 1.8 LEGO-Fin : The kids wanted to make a space for a Lego Minifig to fit so we squared off the penny hole and how you can choose, pennies or Lego characters.

Version 1.8Fin added a version with a FIN! cause they make everything faster :) Version 1.8 now should fit pennies. The earlier version only fit dimes.
Also we made the car more flat so it can be customize easier. Note: the 1.3 version will allow US dimes to fit but they will fall out when flipped over. The 1.8 version holds pennies and you will not get them out easily (hence the hole to push them out-when it's time to recycle). Print takes about an hour. Add pennies and start playing! PLEASE post a MAKE and feedback. :-)
The girls and I are hoping to create a set if I have time this week. First Test print, and the wheels roll! See here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VTn75fFcnG0 Merry Christmas!
Currently printing with a Makerbot Dual, Standard resolution(0.2), 2 Shells, and 15% Fill (but will use 50% later to make it super solid).

Custom cookier designed using CookieCaster: http://www.cookiecaster.com Dimensions:
Longest Length: ~4.0 inches (10.2 cm)

Thickness: 0.04 inches (1.0 mm)

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies

I printed this single print on my single extruder Davinci 1.0 in two colors. Half way through I paused the print, then I left the red cartridge in place but removed the red filament and fed in green from a second cartridge on the side of the printer. This allowed me to print in two colors. See the results at my YouTube Channel. (I suggest supports so the letters turn out better). http://youtu.be/4fC5JwKFIiE

Print the MerryChristmas as normal and then half way through the print, remove the red filament from the extruder and load green. The key is to keep the original cartridge in place or else the Davinci 1.0 will cancel the print.

comments.text: True, the cartridge in the machine will report less than is actually available after the print is done but the second filament can come from anywhere (although I show it from a cartridge) but an under-rated cartridge is a small price to pay to use a second color or different filament to get around the Davinci limits with the stock software. Besides, when the Davinci thinks the original cartridge is done you can remove the filament and use it as the second filament so nothing is wasted.

title: Gulfstream G650 Flat Pack Scale Model

description.text:
This model is based of information and pictures found on Wikipedia.   
The scale Model is 8.5 to 100 ( 8' X 8' )   
This model can be cut out of one sheet of Ply wood. I used 1" thick  wood I had at the shop. Recommended using 1/2"-1" thick wood.

1)Plot All parts on paper or CNC cut 2)Transfer to wood with Carbon paper or double sided tape paper directly to wood 3) Cut all parts out with Jigsaw 4) Sand edged of wood 5) Obtain ~1" X 1" Aluminum L bracket.
Wings Cut- 4 X Long
Horizontal Stabilizer- 4 X Long
Pylons- 4 X Long
Engines- $ X Long 6) Match Drill top and Bottom bracket for Each Part. 7) Match Drill wings, Pylons, Horizontal Stabilizer to each other 8) Mount A wing to the Fuselage and mark holes for drilling. Do this for the Horizontal Stabilizer and Pylons 9) Pant all parts with latex based White paint. 10) Apply Window Vinyl or paint windows in. 11) Assemble with nuts and bolts.

funnel for testing thin walls or general use

Developed from a sketchup model, printed in standard PLA with standard settings except for layer height set to 0.3mm
Note the problem with the funnel print as it narrows caused by insufficient cooling before next layer.  Might be worth using a fan to cool the neck of the funnel then print will be fine.  Wall thickness ended up at 1.15mm average
Note there is infill on some layers which slows print down.  With standard settings this took about 40 minutes to print at 48mm diameter.

description.text: Lever replacement for the EZ3D Phoenix printer. Many thanks to Vandarin who created the original lever replacement and, of course, to EZ3D. Due to a design change there is now an indented circular area behind the wheel. I have also extended the arm holding the wheel knob to make it less likely to break. This was created because my resin original version had a tilted knob holding the wheel bearing which kept filament from being fed properly. This fixed that. IMPORTANT: SEE INSTRUCTIONS!

I feel it is very important to read these instructions thoroughly. Examine this part from all angles as the design may have changed again; I want to be sure the lever works for your design. I myself printed this at medium resolution solid using Slick3r with supports, no raft. Because of the new circular indent you will also need supports unless you are using a non-extruding type 3D printer. I had no problem using a flathead screwdriver to scrape away the supports - you'll need to scrape away the spring indention as well. You will need to sand down the knob that holds the wheel - the fit should be very snug and not loose at all. You also may need to sand down the plastic around where the wheel will be - enough to be sure the wheel turns freely. The holes for the screws and filament need to be poked a few times to be sure anything can enter them without trouble and they are free of debris. I used small screwdrivers to do this. My printer is not enclosed and so warps the ends of my prints a bit. I included a version with weights that prevents this warping. When finished, simply clip off these weights and the arms leading to the lever (you'll enjoy the memories of working with model cars). If you don't have a problem with your prints doing this, you may use the non-weight version instead. I have found that the 3D Lever extender that I uploaded earlier is not needed as there is now enough tension with this design - unless your spring has sprung, and in that case it may be time to get a new spring.

description.text: Light_Cover

The challenge was to be able to print the spokes of a bike wheel on Mendel (0.5 nozzle) using ABS. I used SCAD to generate the components of the wheel. Combined each component manually, and this was my result. A video of the printing process is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j69QjNhJAVU

To print the bike wheel spokes I have manually edited the g-code so this is not for the faint hearted. The scad script used to generate the wheel has been uploaded if anyone else would like to give it a try. I have also uploaded the g-code generated for my machine, but do not expect this will work on another machine, but it can be used as a reference. The script generates a number of objects that need to be edited together. The process I used (there are probably better ways) is as follows.

  • Use the script to generate stl files for; the first side hub and half the rim, 4 sets of spokes, the centre hub, the outer hub, lastly the second half of the rim. When generating each of the 4 spoke stlâ€™s set the parameter c=0 so the spokes are printed flat, so they will slice in one layer. They should be small enough so the only slice to one extrusion width and height.

  • Use your g-code generator to create the g-code for each stl file. I am using ReplicatorG and skeinforge40. Make sure all the stlâ€™s are sliced with the same settings. With all but the first hub and rim, the objects were NOT put on the platform, in effect sliced in mid-air, this meant the layer heights did not have to be changed when the files are merged.

  • Copy to a new file the g-code file for the first (hub and rim) and open in a text editor. Locate the point where the print object finished and add some comments to locate it easily.

  • In each of the other stl files locate the code that prints the object, (that is get rid of the initialize, raft and any support, and the ending) and copy each in turn to the new file, adding comments so you can identify the joins. The order should be;
  • Hub and rim
  • Spoke1
  • Spoke2
  • Centre hub
  • Spoke3
  • Spoke4
  • Outer hub

  • Half rim

  • At each of the joins, correct the E values. In my case the retraction values had to be corrected into the next bit of added code.

  • Now for the spokes. I used skeinlayer to view the g-code to locate the hub end of each spoke and make the Z value equal to the last hub layer plus one layer thickness. Modify the rim end Z values to be the last rim layer plus one layer. For spoke3 and spoke4 centres the Z values will be the last layer of the centre hub plus 1.

  • For each spoke the feed rate has to be reduced to something your printer can handle. Trial and error showed for me the F250 value worked most of the time.

  • Lastly I had to add some gcode to the second rim print as it tried to move the head across the middle taking out the spokes and the centre hub. The rim is lower than the centre. The added g-code moved the head around the outside of the print.
    • I think that is all, but let me know if I appear to have missed anything.

author: stevewilkco

title: Garmin VIRB/GoPro camera mount for Piper Tripacer

description.text: I designed and built this to mount a VIRB onto one of the struts of my Piper PA-22 Tripacer. It should work with any other aircraft strut that has the same profile. Two mounting block designs are provided, one for a GoPro mount and another for the Ram ball mount system.

The main components are printed. The assembly also requires some 5/16 threaded rod, 5/16 nylock nuts, 5/16 washers, 1 1/4" neoprene washers, m8 x 25mm machine screw, m8 nylock nut and 3/4" wide x 5/16 thick automotive weather stripping. For the VIRB a GoPro to VIRB mount adaptor (which comes with the VIRB) or Ram Mounts VIRB adaptor and single socket arm is required.  
Since the attachment point isn't very big I was concerned that if I printed it as part of the mounting block, it might fail at that point. So what I did was design it so that the GoPro adapter would fit into the block, allowing me to use more material at the mount point. This required a more accurate print job than my printer was capable of. That meant some cleanup by hand.  The GoPro mount/adaptor is secured with the m8 machine screw.  
The mounting block is for the Ram Mounts single socket arm part RAP-B-200-1. Clearances are tight and the part or the arm may need to be massaged slightly.   
The assembly is held together with 5/16 threaded rod and nylock nuts. All 5/16" hole need to be cleaned up with a drill. Weather stripping that is squeezed to 5mm is used for a snug fit and to absorb vibration between the strut and the inside of the caps.   
The mounting block(s) are designed with a cavity so that a nylock nut can be used to tighten the rod to the cap. The second outer nut adjusts the tension on the block and the amount of friction provided by neoprene washers between the block and the cap.

It's finally here, the 2011 Hex Desktop Calendar. And just like last year, it's up late! This is a derivative of my 2010 Calendar, which in turn is a derivative of the Hex Connector Toy by 4volt. Enjoy! (Full disclosure, the photo is of the 2010 calendar. I still need to cut one.)

The included files are designed for 1/8th inch thick plywood. I really recommend plywood over, say acrylic, because of the really tight tolerances. Wood has some flex & elasticity to it, whereas more rigid materials have a tendency to snap. 
The file includes 2 colors of line, cut the red (the hex shape), etch the black (the text).
Assemble, and enjoy.
Don't forget to reassemble it each month so that the current month is on top.

description.text: There is a construction set out there that you can buy for $200 on Amazon (when its not sold out) called Fort Magic. Want to try making a DIY version? i found some general information out on the Internet about how to do this. My version of this takes the home made versions out there and kicks it up a notch. DIY link my sister sent me: http://oneshetwoshe.com/2014/07/diy-fort-kit.html Fort Magic web site: http://fortmagic.com/ So, basically I did not buy the Fort Magic set but made my own instead. I made this set for my nephews for Christmas. Most of the parts that I needed I found at the Home Depot. But there were some odds and ends I still needed. The instructions will tell you how to put together the construction set, including which pieces to buy, the cutting tool you will need to get, and how to 3D print out the other parts you can't get!

description.header: Stuff to Buy at Home Depot / Your Favorite Home Center:
description.text:
• 1/2 inch x 100' Roll of SharkBite PEX Pipe (for curved pieces)
  • 1.5 inch diameter PVC pipe (24 inch pieces (for straight PVC pieces))
  • 1.5 inch 3-way connectors... (20 connectors)
  • 1.5 inch 90 degree connectors (10 connectors)
  • 1.5 inch 45 degree connectors (12 connectors)
  • 1.5 inch 4-way connectors (35 connectors)
  • 1.5 inch coupling connectors (10 connectors)
  • A pair of PVC pipe cutters (if you don't have one yet)
  • A large plastic storage container to put everything in.

• Fort Fabric Clips (130 clips)
  • PEX pipe adapters
  • 6 way connectors... finally finished --- there were 35 connectors like these in the Fort Magic kit.

• A ruler
  • A cloth tape measure for measuring the PEX pipe on its curve.
  • A Sharpie pen to mark where to cut the PVC/PEX pipe.
  • Some large zip-lock style freezer storage bags (to separate all the smaller pieces in).
    • Your kids can provide with the help of mom or dad some sheets and blankets to put on the frame of the designs that they build.

3D Printing fabric clips on my Makerbot Replicator 2 printer:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mIQmk1obfnI&list=UUIdwbGLznojs-6VYpo4gbfA

• 60 24" pipes ... no cutting needed, just use 24" pipes you bought.
  • 25 12" pipes ... mark 12 inches over with sharpie and cut with PVC pipe cutter.
  • 24 5" pipes ... repeat...
  • 20 1.5" pipes ... repeat...

• 18 8" pieces
  • 10 16" pieces
  • 8 20" pieces
    • At the end of a batch you might have pieces left over that are not exactly the above measurements. No worries, just add that piece to the group that it matches closest, its still usable.

Right now, I have:
  • a fabric clip thing.
  • a 5/6 way connector thing
  • and PEX pipe adapter thing which you can download.

The clip was designed to clip onto a half inch in diameter piece of PVC pipe.  Currently there is an STL file for a single clip and a THING file specifically for the Makerbot Replicator 2 to print 40 clips at one time.

The PEX pipe is too small to fit into the connectors so I designed an adapter that fits snuggly over the PEX pipe (put one adapter on each end) and then fits nicely into the connectors.  I cut 35 pieces out of the PEX pipe so you would need 70 pieces to cap all the ends of these pieces.

It took awhile to finally design a 6 way connector that worked good. Here it is. I include an STL file of course. But, in addition I include an x3g file for printing 6 connectors at a time on a Makerbot Replicator 2.

I printed all the parts in PLA plastic.  Shells" 2, Infill 25%  
I've used the clips to clip bed sheets and bath towels onto the pipe and it works great.

This is a mount for a 40mm blower fan, designed for the MendelMax 2.0 printer.

Makes Tool Works sells a small 40mm fan that you can find here: http://store.makerstoolworks.com/electronics/blower-fan-24v-40x40x20mm/. This is a blow fan, so it supplies a very good supply of air. I created a mount that allows you to use either one or two of these. First you'll need to insert the fan into the part called Fan Shroud. There is only one way to insert the fan, and it can be a little tricky to get it in. I designed it to be held in place by some M3 x 20 screws and nuts. However, in my case friction was enough to hold it in place. Next attach the Fan Shroud part to the 40mm Blower Bracket, as shown, using two M3 x 8, or M3 x 10 screws and nuts. Finally, attach the assembly to the X carriage using M3 x 10 screws and nuts. It may be hard to get the back nut in place, and it's not really required as long as the front on is in place.

title: Birth thingies (cards, presents etc)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In Belgium we have the tradition that with the coming of a new baby we send birth announcement cards to friends and relatives. Those who come to pay us a visit are then given a small present filled with sweets. To cheer up his room I made him a little chair and a plaque with his name on.
The .svg design files are made in Inkscape (the little chair in FreeCAD as well) and all have my son's name on it. So feel free to replace it with the name of your preference, unless you think this is too much of an effort and settle for the same name.

Card: Cut from 3mm MDF. The card can be put in an envelope that satisfies the dimensions and weight of the (Belgian) standard letter requirements. The bottom part of the card can be separated so that it serves as a foot to hold the card. Not all people realized this, so you may want to put a tiny manual on it. It is a bit loose when cut from 3mm MDF, which is no big deal since it isn't manipulated too much.
Little chair: Cut from 3mm MDF. Requires some glue in the corners when given as a toy for children or to clumsy people. The lid can be opened and the chair filled with sweets. The sides of the chair are engraved with icons symbolizing the four seasons.
Large chair: Cut from 9mm MDF, all parts glued Ã¡nd nailed together to give extra strength since it should withstand severe sitting, throwing, standing upon, pushed-over, smashed-down, opening and closing conditions of small toddlers. They are the worst customers. Letters and star are glued on afterwards.
Small label: Cut from 3mm MDF. The small hole in the middle is to attach a ribbon.
Large name plate: Cut from 3mm MDF. (No separate picture, see first one)

This 5-piece stand organizes several sizes of nail polish and nail files all in a fully rotating, beautiful package. It requires no extra parts to assemble, but sanding tools are recommended to get a smooth spin as well as a little glue to keep acrylic sheets in place. Depending on the 3D printer settings, etc, more or less sanding may be needed to get the correct fit. Made originally as a gift for a friend.

1) Print out each of the 3 bases: bottom base, bottom spinner and top base
2) Laser-cut the two acrylic sheets
3) Sand the spin joints and any rough parts for a smooth spin
3) Carefully snap in each acrylic sheet to the appropriate place, making sure holes on the sheet and the base line up
4) Add a dab of glue to hold the sheets in place
5) Stack the bottom base on the bottom spinner, and the top base on the bottom base
6) Try to spin the top or bottom base. If not smooth enough, sand the joints again until rotation meets your expectations
7) Enjoy!

Love 3d printing with your Thing-o-Matic, but wish there were a better way to see how your print is progressing? Well, today is your lucky day- if you've got a spare hobby servo (the one in the Unicorn works great), then you can make your very own progress gauge!

To use this, you'll need a set of Gen4 electronics and the V2.7 firmware (which is coming soon, but you can get it now by building from source). After you generate a gcode file for your model, run it through the unicorn_progress_meter.py script, which will insert servo control messages to update the position of the servo arm as the build progresses. Use your most 1337 papercraft skills to make a pretty gauge and indicator arm, and you're all set! The latest version of the script can be found here:
https://github.com/makerbot/Makerbot/tree/master/Unicorn/unicorn_progress_meter

title: DIN Mount for EBAY - 5A 75W DC-DC Step-down "BUCK" Converter Module W/ Digital Voltmeter

description.text: Simple and Functional

This is a DIN rail mounting case for the 5A 75W DC-DC Adjustable Step-down Converter Module W/ Digital Voltmeter sold commonly on Ebay for around $5.ooUS. The estimated cost of the assembly = less than $7.00US... http://www.ebay.com/itm/111283659312?_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT or http://www.ebay.com/itm/261667051478?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Tools used in project:
CTC R2x 3d Filament Printer
Phillips head screwdriver
Soldering Iron
I modified an old tip to fit into the brass standoffs
(6) M5.5 self tapping screws (used on PC fans)
(4) M3 Male 6mm x M3 Female 6mm Brass Standoffs
(4) M3x8mm Pan head machine screws.
Most modules come with the standoffs and small aluminum heat sink.

01.) Print the parts 02.) Press and melt in the standoffs in using a soldering iron mod.
I use these settings: (+300ºC for PLA) (+350ºC for ABS) 03.) Attach the DIN rail mounts (4x M5.5 self tapping screws) 04.) Mount the Buck Converter Module. (4x M3 Machine screws) 05.) Insert DC/DC voltage input and output leads. 06.) Place pegs in large holes at the bottom, wide side down (2 Pegs) 07.) Tilt the case upside down and carefully slide the cover into place 07.) Secure cover. (2xM5.5 Self tapping screws) 08.) Snap to DIN rail. 09.) TEST.

description.text: This is a RoBo 3D autoleveling alternative that replaces the stock fan shroud for the hexagon with added capabilities to support a solenoid actuated auto-leveling. Check the instructions for a build guide, or visit the robo3d forum post here: http://forums.robo3dprinter.com/index.php?threads/mike-kellys-solenoid-auto-level-for-stock-r1.3864/#post-34724

In celebration of the season I designed a fan shroud inspired by the stock robo3d one but adds solenoid probing functionality.  
After getting the circuitry and wiring done attaching the fan shroud should take less than 5 minutes. Here's how:

Begin by printing the new fan shroud. 'https://www.dropbox.com/s/lhnkvuxzmx3bk4c/Hexagon%20Probe%20Fan%20Shroud.STL?dl=0' or click the link below Any material is fine and prints without support. I suggest at least 50% infill to give it a good amount of strength since you want to minimize any flexing that could distort you calibration. The links for the solenoid and switch are above, but here they are in order of what you need: 1x $4.95 - Solenoid switch: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/11015
1x $0.184 - $0.513 Per (http://www.amazon.com/Momentary-Hinge-Lever-Micro-Switch/dp/B008SO0IGQ/ref=sr_1_6?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1419447308&sr=1-6&keywords=amico+micro+switch $1.84/10 slow boat or http://www.amazon.com/Pieces-Button-Metal-Lever-Switch/dp/B008LT43P0/ref=sr_1_10?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1419447308&sr=1-10&keywords=amico+micro+switch $6.16 from Prime)Sub Micro Switch 2x~M2- 8mm screws for the switch, could take from existing Z switch
2x M2 - 4mm Self tapping screws $0.563 per ($7.04/25): http://www.mcmaster.com/#96817a840/=v5zsno These are the ones I used but there are many options out there. I think stainless steel is a must as securing into the solenoid was difficult. With the part ready the first step is to secure in the solenoid with the 2 M2-4mm screws from the back http://i.imgur.com/nYK9FeL.gif With the solenoid in place you will then want to attach the switch using any screw around 2mm and at least 8mm in length. It will require tapping into the switch itself but that should be fine. http://i.imgur.com/YFUPcuo.gif The final step is wiring it. As the switch is held down during homing, and a release of the solenoid triggers the switch, then we will be using the Normally Open (NO) pins on the switch. This switch plugs into Z_min on your ramps board, replacing your old Z-min switches For wiring up the solenoid as I suggested above get a set of these: http://www.ebay.com/itm/121357773068?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK:MEBIDX:IT JST 2.0 PH 2 pin connectors. They will work directly off the solenoid so no need to cut wires. This is optional. There are 4 screws holding in the existing 25mm fan, begin by removing them and placing them aside. Be careful when handling the fan to not put too much force on the wires and carefully stow it somewhere. There may then be another screw that holds the stock fan shroud like this:
http://thingiverse-production.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/60/2a/07/75/52/hexfanpic_preview_featured.jpg Unless your fan shroud is held on by friction There is a captive nut on the other side of this screw point so be sure to hold that in place and not lose it while removing the screw. You will then take the new fan shroud solenoid probe assembly and reattach it the same way http://i.imgur.com/d9tQijc.gif The final step with the fan shroud connected to the carriage is to reattach the fan and make sure it still works.

On the circuitry end of the spectrum there's a basic circuit that needs to be made: http://i.imgur.com/Bbs3Mmg.png The mosfet can optionally be replaced with a solid state relay that works with 5v DC. For the mosfet I used the same version that comes on the Ramps board because I had it on hand. There's certainly other options. $1.54 http://www.mouser.com/Search/ProductDetail.aspx?R=STP55NF06Lvirtualkey51120000virtualkey511-STP55NF06L MOSFET STP55NF06L
$0.18 http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Fairchild-Semiconductor/1N4001/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMtbRapU8LlZD6Aoap19JQAxIIoiB5N1kdc%3d 1N4001 - For a diode I used an 1N4004 but you could probably just as well use a LED and a 100ohm resistor.
$0.10 http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/KOA-Speer/MF1-4LCT52R103J/?qs=sGAEpiMZZMtlubZbdhIBID0wPG5x1Smo7s1vIxRENeo%3d 10k Resistor 1/4W 5% tolerance $1.20 per ($11.98 total ) http://www.ebay.com/itm/301120877446?_trksid=p2059210.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT Step down power converter

I have provided pre-modified firmware available for Download here https://www.dropbox.com/s/4ydxgmeehxv6avt/Robo3dR1V2_Solenoid_5-16.zip?dl=0 Robo3d with 5/16" Rods https://www.dropbox.com/s/zx9cs4alufxje4g/Robo3dR1V2_Solenoid_M8.zip?dl=0 Robo3d with M8 Rods or click the link below The firmware consists of a few main changes, by order of what you need to do: Z_Probe_Offset: In configuration.h there is a variable Z_Probe_Offset that needs to be adjusted. This can be done two ways. The first is to modify the firmware value. Your value should be somewhere between 1 and 1.5, you will need to calibrate this yourself. define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 1.0 The second is to use the M565 command, eg G28 ; Home all axis
M565 Z1.0 ; Z probe offset of 1.0mm, adjust for your printer
G29 ;Run autolevel routine. X and Y Offsets The Y and Z probe offset values will be set as such // these are the offsets to the probe relative to the extruder tip (Hotend - Probe)
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 24.7
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 21.5 Uncomment define PROBE_SERVO_DEACTIVATION_DELAY 300 Enabling Servos: At the very bottom of configuration.h you need to enable service by uncommenting: define NUM_SERVOS 3 // Servo index starts with 0 for M280 command Setting to at least 1 Then uncommenting define SERVO_ENDSTOPS {-1, -1, 0} // Servo index for X, Y, Z. Disable with -1
define SERVO_ENDSTOP_ANGLES {0,0, 0,0, 0,0} // X,Y,Z Axis Extend and Retract angles Setting the angle to 0 In pins.h you need to add a new value: define Z_PROBE_PIN 63 // IO pin, 5v, extend and retract touch probe
Using the Pin 63 as our control pin. You can change this for any other digital output. Place this between define SDPOWER -1
define SDSS 53
define LED_PIN 13[/code] And endif if MOTHERBOARD == 33 || MOTHERBOARD == 35 || MOTHERBOARD == 67 || MOTHERBOARD == 68
define FAN_PIN 9 // (Sprinter config)
else[/code] The biggest revision is modifying conifguration.h with these calls:
[code]
static void engage_z_probe(int d = 100) { //lower z probe
digitalWrite(Z_PROBE_PIN, HIGH);
delay(d);
} static void retract_z_probe(int d = 100) { // raise z probe
digitalWrite(Z_PROBE_PIN, LOW);
delay(d);
}[/code] Commenting out the old engage and retract commands That should be everything you need to do to get running! Again the only thing you need to add is the Z_offset, everything else is done for you.

comments.text:
Hey Mkelly
Been a fan of your robo3d posts for awhile. Having used these great little step down regulators in your description for several projects I thought I would mention there is an alternative way to control the solenoid voltage supply (without a mosfet) that may be beneficial. All you need to do is lift pin 5 of the lm2596 (On/off pin) http://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/lm2596.pdf and solder a female jumper wire to the newly lifted pin 5, use some heatshrink to tidy up the solder connection and connect the jumper into the RAMPS control pin of your choice. One minor software change is required if you use this method. The logic high/low need to be inverted. (see modified code below). There may be some additional code required. Im not sure what state the control pin is initialized to with the default firmware, ideally it should be pulled high or left floating until the auto level functions are called. Ill post a confirmation when i can look at the default pin state.
Thanks for all the great advice.

title: Draisienne bike (IKEA hack collection) by Andreas Bhend and Samuel N. Bernier

description.text:
More cool things to come on http://www.lefabshop.fr/ In november 2012, Core77 made an article on their blog about one of my projects, a collection of 3D printed lampshades made to repair IKEA lamps. At the end of the page, the writer (Ray) made a suggestion : "Where Andreas Bhend's recently-seen IKEA hacks included instructions Ã  la the Swedish furniture giant's pictographic booklets, Bernier has seen fit to customize a part of the whole. But if they're disparate yet equally creative approaches to DIY making, perhaps the next step is for the two to join forces: Andreas, if you're reading this, we'd love to see you guys collaborate on a series of IKEA hacks with bespoke 3D printed parts and instructions..." That's exactly what we did. Andreas is a student in the east of Switzerland while I work full time for le FabShop, a 3D printing startup in Paris (France).
We didn't know each other, but were motivated by the project. Andreas took the train to Paris where we spent two days and a half doing this :

Download the PDF here : www.instructables/lefabshop
or here http://issuu.com/andreasbhend/docs/draisienne
You'll need 3 times the handle and 4 times the wheel plates. To see our next awesome projects, follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/LeFabShop
Facebook : http://www.facebook.com/pages/Le-fabshop/306604872773359?fref=ts
Or visit our website : www.lefabshop.fr

author: joesow

description.text:
The flexible insert was made with PolyMakr's PolyFlex filament. Less flexible than Ninjaflex but easier to work with. The holder itself is in PolyMax. Done in sort of a rush, so it is unfinished, but it does what it's supposed to do. The idea was to use a flexible insert to take up the shocks from bumping the tree and from random attacks by the cat. It also makes measurements of the tree less critical than if the tree were to go directly into a rigid base. I'm not a mechanical design engineer, so I'm not saying it was a great idea, but it does keep the tree from falling over :)  The holes in the base are so I can use a rod to help push the insert out of the stand if I need to, because there's nothing to hold onto to pull it out. The hole in the insert was a custom job to fit the tree I have. It was done in Rhino, as a first project.   
The STL file looked really messed up in S3D, but it sliced fine and the g-code was fine as well.
Flexible filament for the insert. The cutout in the insert was custom, for the tree I have, so this is not really usable by others at this point.
Remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286367 with hands, arms and body cut to make printing less prone to errors

author: Morphiapp

description.text:
My puppy eats his food way too fast.  They didn't have the right sized insert at the store, so I made my own.  I made one with a cutout in the middle to insert a suction cup that I had lying around.  The other file (dog_bowl_no_cutout) is just flat along the bottom if you would like to secure it to the bottom of the bowl with tape or something else.  
I've included my OpenSCAD file if you want to change any of the measurements.  The STLs I've uploaded are 110mm in diameter, with the outer cones measuring  53mm tall and the inner cone measuring 33mm tall.  
Marked as work in progress because I haven't finished printing the model with the cutout for the suction cup.  I might also try to clean up the OpenSCAD file to make it easier to customize.
